awd_titl_txt: The new identity of galectin-3 as a glycosaminoglycan binding protein
awd_abstract_narration:
Glycan-binding proteins are crucial for a wide range of biological processes. They belong to two distinct groups: lectins and glycosaminoglycan (GAG)-binding proteins (GAGBPs). A member of one group rarely possesses the characteristics of both groups. The human lectin Galectin-3 (Gal-3) is a member of the first group. This project is based on the finding that Gal-3, a lectin, actually possesses characteristics of a GAGBP. The current study investigates these newly-discovered characteristics of Gal-3. The research is integrated with educational activities through an initiative called "From Bench to Blackboard." This initiative introduces glycobiology to high school students and K-12 teachers through lab- and web-based approaches. The anticipated results from the proposed work is revealing hitherto unknown properties of Gal-3 and will inspire new research activities involving Gal-3 and GAGs.

Gal-3 is one of the most extensively studied human lectins but it has never been reported as a GAGBP. However, preliminary data for this study show that Gal-3 binds to sulfated GAGs and proteoglycans. The proposed research elucidates the detailed interactions of Gal-3 with GAGs and proteoglycans. The length and sulfation level of GAGs, that are optimal for binding by Gal-3, are determined by calorimetry and spectroscopy. The GAG binding site of Gal-3 is being delineated with the use of site directed mutagenesis. Various biophysical techniques are employed to study non-covalent cross-linking of Gal-3 by GAGs and proteoglycans. In addition, competitive cross-linking of Gal-3 by GAGs and glycoproteins is also being examined. Information obtained from this research is redefining the binding properties of Gal-3 and providing a foundation for discovering Gal-3 dependent cellular and extracellular functions of GAGs and proteoglycans.

por.por_cntn:
The new identity of galectin-3 as a glycosaminoglycan binding protein

Intellectual merit:

Glycan-binding proteins (GBPs) mediate numerous biological events by interacting with glycosylated (sugar-coated) ligands. GBPs belong to two subgroups: lectins and glycosaminoglycan (GAG)-binding proteins (GAGBPs). The structures of the binding sites of lectins, their preferred ligands and mode of actions are fundamentally different from those of GAGBPs. While lectins interact with specific glycoproteins, GAGBPs recognize GAGs and proteoglycans. A member of one subgroup is not expected to possess the characteristics of both. The current NSF-funded project, however, established that human lectin Galectin-3 (Gal-3) is a notable exception to that rule. Data obtained through this project unequivocally showed that, besides being a lectin that binds to N- and O-linked glycoproteins, Gal-3 has the properties of a GAGBP. The project revealed the following unexpected characteristics of Gal-3. (i) Gal-3 interacts with sulfated GAGs (heparin and chondroitin sulfates) and chondroitin sulfate proteoglycans (CSPGs) (Figure 1). (ii) Sulfated GAGs and CSPGs specifically bind to the LacNAc/lactose binding site of Gal-3. (iii) Four positively charged amino acids in the vicinity of the LacNAc/lactose binding site of Gal-3 play important roles in GAG binding (Figure 2). (iv) While, heparin, chondroitin sulfate B (CSB) and E (CSE) are found to be monovalent ligands of Gal-3, chondroitin sulfate A (CSA), chondroitin sulfate C (CSC) and bovine CSPG engage in multivalent binding with Gal-3 and form cross-linked complexes (Figure 3). (v) Constituent monosaccharides and the sulfation patterns of GAGs modulate their cross-linking abilities and affinities for Gal-3 (Figure 3). (vi) By using CSA and CSC as baits or capturing agents, Gal-3 was purified through a newly developed detection method named Capture and Release (CaRe) (Figure 4). (vii) It was determined that Gal-3 bound to GAG chains through a mechanism named bind and jump (Figure 5). While full length GAG chains bind to Gal-3 with micromolar affinity, shorter GAG fragments bind to Gal-3 with weak affinity. (viii) GAGs including CSA and CSC perturbed Gal-3-glycoprotein cross-linked complexes (Figure 6).

Thus, the outcome of this project clearly shows hitherto unanticipated functional ties of Gal-3 with sulfated GAGs and proteoglycans. The present project shades new light on known functions of Gal-3 and also provides a foundation for discovering Gal-3 dependent cellular and extracellular functions of GAGs and proteoglycans. The multitasking ability of Gal-3 is likely to be rooted in its capacity to interact with two different domains of glycoconjugates (GAG/proteoglycans and glycoproteins). 

 Gal-3 has received enormous attention because of the important roles it plays in numerous cellular and extracellular processes including metastasis, inflammation, pathogen invasion and neural development. Gal-3 is also involved in specific renal, cardiac, ocular and vascular events. The data obtained through the current project dramatically expand the types of binding partners of Gal-3, which, in turn, explain the intriguing functional diversity of Gal-3. Recently, Gal-3 has been implicated in the pathogenesis of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) caused by SARS-associated coronavirus (SARS-CoV). Gal-3 is a potential target for the treatment of COVID-19 disease and it is emerging as a prognostic biomarker of severe COVID-19. The insight gained from the current study can shed light on the roles of Gal-3 in SARS cause by coronavirus.

 The project successfully reached all the milestones mentioned in the proposal, produced seven publications (including the one published just before the start date of the project), multiple meeting abstracts, student awards, reagents and a provisional patent. One of the publications led to an invitation from a prestigious publishing house to edit a book on Glycoscience. This research work helped receive two invitations: one to chair a poster session at an Experimental Biology/ASBMB meeting (virtual) and the other was to deliver a Flash Talk at the Protein Society Annual Conference (virtual).

Broader impacts:

The knowledge gained from this project was transferred not only to the peers but also to non-experts and students at different levels through different platforms. Concepts developed by this project were shared with undergraduates and graduates in classrooms through Bench to Blackboard initiative mentioned in the proposal. Graduate as well as undergraduate researchers (including women and minorities) were trained and outreach activities involving high school students were conducted under this project. Results were also shared at local, regional and national scientific conferences.

Gal-3 is involved in the pathogenesis of some major human diseases (including SARS, heart disease and cancer) and Gal-3 could be targeted for their treatment and detection. The dual specificity of Gal-3, elucidated by the current project, will help better understand the roles of Gal-3 in these disease conditions. Understanding the molecular basis of the functional diversity of Gal-3 will help formulate more efficient approaches to manage these diseases. Thus, the impact of this project on society is likely to be profound.
